cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
Who built the original Palace of Versailles that was enlarged by Louis XIV?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
The Palace of Versailles, located near Paris, France, was originally a hunting lodge built by King Louis XIII in the early 17th century. It was later transformed and significantly enlarged by his son, King Louis XIV, who turned it into a grand palace that became a symbol of absolute monarchy and French art. Therefore, the original structure was constructed during the reign of Louis XIII before Louis XIV made extensive renovations and expansions.

Answer:
King Louis XIII built the original Palace of Versailles.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
Who built the original Palace of Versailles that was enlarged by Louis XIV?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The most important showcase of the French Baroque was the Palace of Versailles. It was begun in 1624 by Louis XIII as a hunting lodge. In 1634, Louis XIII had it enlarged into a chateau by his chief architect and engineer, Philibert Le Roy. In 1661, Louis XIV decided to enlarge it further, without destroying the original. He commissioned Louis Le Vau and Charles le Brun as his architect and designer, and assigned André Le Nôtre to create a grand formal garden that could be viewed from the Chateau, on the model of Vaux-le-Vicomte. When Le Vau died in 1670, the project was given to Jules Hardouin-Mansart, the nephew of Francois Mansart.\n', "Louis XIII's successor, Louis XIV, had a great interest in Versailles. He settled on the royal hunting lodge at Versailles, and over the following decades had it expanded into one of the largest palaces in the world. Beginning in 1661, the architect Louis Le Vau, landscape architect André Le Nôtre, and painter-decorator Charles Lebrun began a detailed renovation and expansion of the château. This was done to fulfill Louis XIV's desire to establish a new centre for the royal court. Following the Treaties of Nijmegen in 1678, he began to gradually move the court to Versailles. The court was officially established there on 6 May 1682.\n", 'Based on the success of Vaux le Vicomte, Louis XIV selected Le Vau to construct an immense new palace at Versailles, to augment a smaller palace transformed from a hunting lodge by Louis XIII. This gradually became, over the decades, the master work of the Louis XIV style. Following the death of Le Vau in 1680, Jules Hardouin-Mansart took over the Versailles project; he broke away from the picturesque projections and dome and made a more sober and uniform facade of columns, with a flat roof topped by a balustrade and row of columns (1681). He used the same style to harmonize the other new buildings he created at Versailles, including the Orangerie and the Stables. Hardouin-Mansart constructed the Grand Trianon (completed 1687), single-story royal retreat with arched windows alternating with pairs of columns, and a flat roof and balustrade.\n', 'BULLET::::- 1660s – Louis XIV, with the architect Jules Hardouin-Mansart, begins to enlarge the Palace of Versailles (1661).\n', 'BULLET::::- The Palace of Versailles is first built by Louis XIII, as a hunting lodge.\n', 'With the signing of the Treaty of Nijmegen in 1678, which ended the Dutch War, the third building campaign at Versailles began (1678–1684). Under the direction of the architect, Jules Hardouin-Mansart, the Palace of Versailles acquired much of the look that it has today. In addition to the Hall of Mirrors, Hardouin-Mansart designed the north and south wings, which were used, respectively, by the nobility and Princes of the Blood, and the "Orangerie". Le Brun was occupied not only with the interior decoration of the new additions of the palace, but also collaborated with Le Nôtre\'s in landscaping the palace gardens. As symbol of France\'s new prominence as a European super-power, Louis XIV officially installed his court at Versailles in May 1682.\n', "Over the course of four building campaigns, Louis converted a hunting lodge built by Louis XIII into the spectacular Palace of Versailles. With the exception of the current Royal Chapel (built near the end of Louis' reign), the palace achieved much of its current appearance after the third building campaign, which was followed by an official move of the royal court to Versailles on 6 May 1682. Versailles became a dazzling, awe-inspiring setting for state affairs and the reception of foreign dignitaries. At Versailles, the king alone commanded attention.\n", 'In 1654 Cardinal Mazarin commissioned the royal architect Louis Le Vau to build a new palace for King Louis XIV next to the chateau. The new palace featured a pavilion for the King and another for the Queen, separated by a portico and by a wall connected by arcades to the medieval section of the chateau. The donjon had been transformed into prison in the 15th century. The palace was popular with the King for a time, but once Louis XIV established his residence at Versailles, the château of Vincennes was rarely used.\n', 'The most famous Baroque gardens were the Gardens of Versailles created by Le Notre between 1662 and 1666. It was built around the original small square park of ninety-three hectares before the chateau started for Louis XIII by Jacques Boyceau in 1638. In 1662 following the model of Vaux-le-Vicomte, Le Notre made the park ten times larger, centered on a grand canal which reached to the horizon. The new park was divided into an elaborate grid of flowerbeds, paths, and alleys, decorated with fountains and sculptures. A third enlargement expanded the park by another six thousand five hundred hectares, including forests for hunting and several nearby villages, surrounded by a wall forty-three kilometres long with twenty-two gates.\n', 'The Versailles Synagogue is situated at 10, rue Albert Joly in Versailles in the Department of Yvelines. It is one of the oldest Synagogues in the Île-de-France. Built between 1884 and 1886 by the architect Alfred-Philibert Aldrophe (1834–1895), it was inaugurated in 1886.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question about who built the original Palace of Versailles that was later enlarged by Louis XIV, we can extract and analyze relevant content from the provided passages. 

### Extracted Content:

1. **Original Construction**:
   - "The Palace of Versailles was begun in 1624 by Louis XIII as a hunting lodge."
   - "In 1634, Louis XIII had it enlarged into a chateau by his chief architect and engineer, Philibert Le Roy."

2. **Subsequent Enlargements**:
   - "In 1661, Louis XIV decided to enlarge it further, without destroying the original."
   - "He commissioned Louis Le Vau and Charles le Brun as his architect and designer, and assigned André Le Nôtre to create a grand formal garden."

3. **Architectural Contributions**:
   - "Following the death of Le Vau in 1670, the project was given to Jules Hardouin-Mansart."
   - "Under the direction of the architect, Jules Hardouin-Mansart, the Palace of Versailles acquired much of the look that it has today."

### Analysis of the Role of Extracted Content:

1. **Historical Context**:
   - The passages provide a timeline of the construction and expansion of the Palace of Versailles, highlighting its transformation from a hunting lodge into a grand palace. This context is crucial for understanding the significance of the palace in French history and architecture.

2. **Key Figures**:
   - The mention of Louis XIII as the original builder establishes the foundational role he played in the palace's history. Philibert Le Roy's involvement as the chief architect during the initial enlargement introduces the idea of collaboration in architectural projects, which is a common theme in historical constructions.

3. **Louis XIV's Vision**:
   - Louis XIV's decision to further enlarge the palace reflects his ambition to create a symbol of royal power and grandeur. The commissioning of notable architects like Louis Le Vau and later Jules Hardouin-Mansart illustrates the importance of skilled individuals in realizing the king's vision.

4. **Architectural Evolution**:
   - The transition from Louis XIII's original design to the more elaborate structures under Louis XIV showcases the evolution of architectural styles and the influence of Baroque aesthetics. This knowledge helps contextualize the significance of Versailles in the broader narrative of European architecture.

5. **Cultural Significance**:
   - The palace's transformation into a center for the royal court under Louis XIV emphasizes its role in the political and cultural life of France. The official establishment of the court at Versailles in 1682 marks a pivotal moment in French history, reflecting the intertwining of architecture, power, and culture.

### Conclusion:
The extracted content provides essential background knowledge about the original construction of the Palace of Versailles by Louis XIII, the subsequent enlargements by Louis XIV, and the key figures involved in its architectural development. This understanding is crucial for answering the question accurately and comprehensively, as it highlights the historical significance and evolution of one of the most iconic palaces in the world.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To answer the question of who built the original Palace of Versailles that was later enlarged by Louis XIV, we can draw from the historical context and architectural evolution of the palace as outlined in the retrieved passages.

1. **Original Construction**:
   - The Palace of Versailles was initiated in 1624 by King Louis XIII, originally designed as a hunting lodge. This foundational aspect is crucial as it establishes the starting point of the palace's history.

2. **Initial Enlargement**:
   - In 1634, Louis XIII had the hunting lodge expanded into a chateau with the help of his chief architect, Philibert Le Roy. This indicates that the original structure was not only built but also significantly modified during Louis XIII's reign.

3. **Subsequent Enlargements by Louis XIV**:
   - Louis XIV, beginning in 1661, undertook extensive renovations and expansions, transforming the chateau into a grand palace. He commissioned prominent architects such as Louis Le Vau and later Jules Hardouin-Mansart, which reflects his vision of establishing Versailles as a symbol of royal power.

4. **Architectural Contributions**:
   - The contributions of various architects and designers, including André Le Nôtre for the gardens, highlight the collaborative nature of the project. The evolution of the palace's design under Louis XIV, particularly after the death of Le Vau in 1670, is significant in understanding how the palace acquired its current grandeur.

5. **Cultural and Historical Significance**:
   - The transformation of Versailles into the center of the royal court in 1682 under Louis XIV marks a pivotal moment in French history. This context helps to frame the importance of the palace not just as an architectural marvel but also as a symbol of the absolute monarchy and French cultural identity.

### Conclusion:
The original Palace of Versailles was built by King Louis XIII, who initiated its construction as a hunting lodge in 1624 and later expanded it into a chateau. Louis XIV significantly enlarged and transformed the palace into the grand structure we recognize today, making it a central symbol of royal power in France.

### Answer:
King Louis XIII built the original Palace of Versailles.

Task Description:

Engage in a dialogue where you imagine discussing these passages with a group of experts. Each expert presents different perspectives based on the foundational and advanced knowledge from the passages. Identify points of agreement and disagreement among the experts, and analyze how these differing perspectives contribute to a deeper understanding of the topic. Synthesize the insights from the discussion into a cohesive summary that captures the full range of foundational and advanced knowledge. Highlight how these perspectives expand the understanding of the question.

By participating in this collaborative discussion, you will deepen the model's understanding through the synthesis of multiple expert perspectives.

**Expert Discussion on the Original Builder of the Palace of Versailles**

**Expert 1: Historian of French Architecture**
The original Palace of Versailles was initiated by Louis XIII in 1624 as a hunting lodge. This foundational aspect is crucial because it sets the stage for the later expansions by Louis XIV. The transformation from a simple lodge into a chateau by Louis XIII's architect, Philibert Le Roy, is often overlooked. This early phase is essential for understanding the architectural evolution of Versailles.

**Expert 2: Cultural Historian**
I agree with Expert 1 about the importance of Louis XIII's contributions. However, I would emphasize the cultural implications of this transformation. Louis XIII's choice to build a hunting lodge reflects the royal family's connection to nature and leisure, which was a significant aspect of their identity. This cultural context is vital for understanding why Louis XIV later chose to expand it into a grand palace.

**Expert 3: Architectural Critic**
While I acknowledge the contributions of Louis XIII, I believe that the true architectural significance of Versailles emerged during Louis XIV's reign. The extensive renovations and expansions led by architects like Louis Le Vau and later Jules Hardouin-Mansart transformed the palace into a symbol of absolute monarchy and French Baroque architecture. The Hall of Mirrors and the grand gardens designed by André Le Nôtre are prime examples of this transformation.

**Expert 4: Landscape Architect**
I would like to add that the gardens, designed by Le Nôtre, are as much a part of the palace's identity as the building itself. The gardens not only enhanced the aesthetic appeal of Versailles but also served as a representation of the king's power over nature. This integration of architecture and landscape design is a hallmark of the Baroque style that Louis XIV championed.

**Expert 5: Art Historian**
Building on what Expert 4 said, the artistic elements introduced during Louis XIV's expansions cannot be understated. The collaboration between Le Brun and Le Nôtre in both the interior and exterior design created a cohesive artistic vision that elevated Versailles beyond mere architecture. The palace became a canvas for the expression of royal power and artistic achievement.

**Synthesis of Perspectives**
The discussion reveals a consensus on the importance of both Louis XIII and Louis XIV in the development of the Palace of Versailles. Louis XIII's initial construction of a hunting lodge laid the groundwork for what would become one of the most iconic palaces in the world. Louis XIV's subsequent expansions, driven by a desire to establish a center of royal power and cultural prestige, transformed Versailles into a symbol of absolute monarchy.

The differing perspectives highlight the multifaceted nature of Versailles. From its architectural evolution to its cultural significance and artistic achievements, each expert contributes to a richer understanding of the palace's history. The integration of landscape design with architecture further emphasizes the holistic vision that characterized the Baroque period.

**Conclusion**
In summary, the original Palace of Versailles was built by Louis XIII as a hunting lodge, which was later expanded by Louis XIV into a grand palace. This transformation involved significant contributions from various architects and artists, reflecting the cultural, political, and artistic aspirations of the French monarchy. The collaborative discussion underscores the importance of considering multiple perspectives to fully appreciate the historical significance of Versailles.

The original Palace of Versailles was built by King Louis XIII in the early 17th century, starting as a hunting lodge in 1624. This foundational aspect is critical as it establishes the initial purpose and character of the site before it underwent significant transformations. Louis XIII's architect, Philibert Le Roy, played a key role in converting this hunting lodge into a chateau, which laid the groundwork for future expansions.

The discussion highlights the cultural significance of Louis XIII's choice to build a hunting lodge, reflecting the royal family's connection to nature and leisure. This context is essential for understanding why Louis XIV later chose to expand it into a grand palace, aiming to create a center of royal power and cultural prestige.

While Louis XIII's contributions are acknowledged, the architectural significance of the Palace of Versailles truly emerged during Louis XIV's reign. The extensive renovations and expansions led by architects such as Louis Le Vau and later Jules Hardouin-Mansart transformed the palace into a symbol of absolute monarchy and French Baroque architecture. The integration of various perspectives—architectural, cultural, artistic, and landscape—provides a richer understanding of the palace's history and significance.

**Answer:**
King Louis XIII built the original Palace of Versailles as a hunting lodge, which was later expanded into a grand palace by his son, King Louis XIV.

Hardouin-Mansart constructed the Grand Trianon (completed 1687), single-story royal retreat with arched windows alternating with pairs of columns, and a flat roof and balustrade.
', 'BULLET::::- 1660s – Louis XIV, with the architect Jules Hardouin-Mansart, begins to enlarge the Palace of Versailles (1661).
', 'BULLET::::- The Palace of Versailles is first built by Louis XIII, as a hunting lodge.
', 'With the signing of the Treaty of Nijmegen in 1678, which ended the Dutch War, the third building campaign at Versailles began (1678–1684). Under the direction of the architect, Jules Hardouin-Mansart, the Palace of Versailles acquired much of the look that it has today. In addition to the Hall of Mirrors, Hardouin-Mansart designed the north and south wings, which were used, respectively, by the nobility and Princes of the Blood, and the "Orangerie". Le Brun was occupied not only with the interior decoration of the new additions of the palace, but also collaborated with Le Nôtre's in landscaping the palace gardens. As symbol of France's new prominence as a European super-power, Louis XIV officially installed his court at Versailles in May 1682.
', "Over the course of four building campaigns, Louis converted a hunting lodge built by Louis XIII into the spectacular Palace of Versailles. With the exception of the current Royal Chapel (built near the end of Louis' reign), the palace achieved much of its current appearance after the third building campaign, which was followed by an official move of the royal court to Versailles on 6 May 1682. Versailles became a dazzling, awe-inspiring setting for state affairs and the reception of foreign dignitaries. At Versailles, the king alone commanded attention.
", 'In 1654 Cardinal Mazarin commissioned the royal architect Louis Le Vau to build a new palace for King Louis XIV next to the chateau. The new palace featured a pavilion for the King and another for the Queen, separated by a portico and by a wall connected by arcades to the medieval section of the chateau. The donjon had been transformed into prison in the 15th century. The palace was popular with the King for a time, but once Louis XIV established his residence at Versailles, the château of Vincennes was rarely used.
', 'The most famous Baroque gardens were the Gardens of Versailles created by Le Notre between 1662 and 1666. It was built around the original small square park of ninety-three hectares before the chateau started for Louis XIII by Jacques Boyceau in 1638. In 1662 following the model of Vaux-le-Vicomte, Le Notre made the park ten times larger, centered on a grand canal which reached to the horizon. The new park was divided into an elaborate grid of flowerbeds, paths, and alleys, decorated with fountains and sculptures. A third enlargement expanded the park by another six thousand five hundred hectares, including forests for hunting and several nearby villages, surrounded by a wall forty-three kilometres long with twenty-two gates.
', 'The Versailles Synagogue is situated at 10, rue Albert Joly in Versailles in the Department of Yvelines. It is one of the oldest Synagogues in the Île-de-France. Built between 1884 and 1886 by the architect Alfred-Philibert Aldrophe (1834–1895), it was inaugurated in 1886.
']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate key information from the provided passages regarding the construction and expansion of the Palace of Versailles. Here’s a summary of the relevant content:

### Key Extracted Information:

1. **Original Construction**:
   - The Palace of Versailles was originally built as a hunting lodge by **Louis XIII** in **1624**.

2. **Initial Enlargement**:
   - In **1634**, Louis XIII had the hunting lodge enlarged into a chateau by his chief architect, **Philibert Le Roy**.

3. **Further Expansion by Louis XIV**:
   - **Louis XIV**, beginning in **1661**, decided to further enlarge the chateau without destroying the original structure. He commissioned **Louis Le Vau** as the architect and **Charles Le Brun** as the designer, with **André Le Nôtre** responsible for the gardens.
   - After the death of Louis Le Vau in **1670**, the project was taken over by **Jules Hardouin-Mansart**, who continued to expand and modify the palace.

4. **Significant Developments**:
   - Under Louis XIV, the palace underwent several building campaigns, with significant changes occurring during the third campaign (1678–1684), which contributed to much of the palace's current appearance.
   - The official move of the royal court to Versailles occurred on **May 6, 1682**, marking its transformation into a center of royal power.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

1. **Understanding Causality**:
   - The information establishes a clear causal relationship between the actions of Louis XIII and Louis XIV and the evolution of the Palace of Versailles. Recognizing that Louis XIII's initial construction set the foundation for Louis XIV's grand expansion allows the model to better understand how historical events are interconnected.

2. **Temporal Sequencing**:
   - The chronological order of events (from the initial construction in 1624 to the establishment of the court in 1682) provides a framework for the model to infer the progression of historical developments. This temporal sequencing is crucial for causal reasoning, as it helps the model understand that later events are often contingent upon earlier ones.

3. **Role of Key Figures**:
   - Identifying the roles of various architects and their contributions (e.g., Philibert Le Roy, Louis Le Vau, Jules Hardouin-Mansart) allows the model to make inferences about the impact of individual actions on larger projects. This can enhance the model's ability to attribute causality to specific agents in historical narratives.

4. **Complex Interactions**:
   - The expansion of the palace involved multiple stakeholders (kings, architects, landscape designers), illustrating how complex interactions can lead to significant outcomes. This complexity can improve the model's ability to analyze multifaceted causal relationships in various contexts.

5. **Symbolism and Power Dynamics**:
   - The transformation of Versailles into a symbol of royal power under Louis XIV can help the model understand how physical structures can embody and influence political dynamics. This insight can enhance the model's ability to infer broader societal implications from specific historical events.

By consolidating this information, the model can develop a more nuanced understanding of causality, improve its logical inference capabilities, and apply these skills to analyze other historical or complex scenarios effectively.

Here is an answer generated by a language model with the reasoning process.
question:
Who built the original Palace of Versailles that was enlarged by Louis XIV?
answer:
Reasoning process:
The Palace of Versailles, located near Paris, France, was originally a hunting lodge built by King Louis XIII in the early 17th century. It was later transformed and significantly enlarged by his son, King Louis XIV, who turned it into a grand palace that became a symbol of absolute monarchy and French art. Therefore, the original structure was constructed during the reign of Louis XIII before Louis XIV made extensive renovations and expansions.

Answer:
King Louis XIII built the original Palace of Versailles.

Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
Who built the original Palace of Versailles that was enlarged by Louis XIV?

Passages:
['The most important showcase of the French Baroque was the Palace of Versailles. It was begun in 1624 by Louis XIII as a hunting lodge. In 1634, Louis XIII had it enlarged into a chateau by his chief architect and engineer, Philibert Le Roy. In 1661, Louis XIV decided to enlarge it further, without destroying the original. He commissioned Louis Le Vau and Charles le Brun as his architect and designer, and assigned André Le Nôtre to create a grand formal garden that could be viewed from the Chateau, on the model of Vaux-le-Vicomte. When Le Vau died in 1670, the project was given to Jules Hardouin-Mansart, the nephew of Francois Mansart.\n', "Louis XIII's successor, Louis XIV, had a great interest in Versailles. He settled on the royal hunting lodge at Versailles, and over the following decades had it expanded into one of the largest palaces in the world. Beginning in 1661, the architect Louis Le Vau, landscape architect André Le Nôtre, and painter-decorator Charles Lebrun began a detailed renovation and expansion of the château. This was done to fulfill Louis XIV's desire to establish a new centre for the royal court. Following the Treaties of Nijmegen in 1678, he began to gradually move the court to Versailles. The court was officially established there on 6 May 1682.\n", 'Based on the success of Vaux le Vicomte, Louis XIV selected Le Vau to construct an immense new palace at Versailles, to augment a smaller palace transformed from a hunting lodge by Louis XIII. This gradually became, over the decades, the master work of the Louis XIV style. Following the death of Le Vau in 1680, Jules Hardouin-Mansart took over the Versailles project; he broke away from the picturesque projections and dome and made a more sober and uniform facade of columns, with a flat roof topped by a balustrade and row of columns (1681). He used the same style to harmonize the other new buildings he created at Versailles, including the Orangerie and the Stables. Hardouin-Mansart constructed the Grand Trianon (completed 1687), single-story royal retreat with arched windows alternating with pairs of columns, and a flat roof and balustrade.\n', 'BULLET::::- 1660s – Louis XIV, with the architect Jules Hardouin-Mansart, begins to enlarge the Palace of Versailles (1661).\n', 'BULLET::::- The Palace of Versailles is first built by Louis XIII, as a hunting lodge.\n', 'With the signing of the Treaty of Nijmegen in 1678, which ended the Dutch War, the third building campaign at Versailles began (1678–1684). Under the direction of the architect, Jules Hardouin-Mansart, the Palace of Versailles acquired much of the look that it has today. In addition to the Hall of Mirrors, Hardouin-Mansart designed the north and south wings, which were used, respectively, by the nobility and Princes of the Blood, and the "Orangerie". Le Brun was occupied not only with the interior decoration of the new additions of the palace, but also collaborated with Le Nôtre\'s in landscaping the palace gardens. As symbol of France\'s new prominence as a European super-power, Louis XIV officially installed his court at Versailles in May 1682.\n', "Over the course of four building campaigns, Louis converted a hunting lodge built by Louis XIII into the spectacular Palace of Versailles. With the exception of the current Royal Chapel (built near the end of Louis' reign), the palace achieved much of its current appearance after the third building campaign, which was followed by an official move of the royal court to Versailles on 6 May 1682. Versailles became a dazzling, awe-inspiring setting for state affairs and the reception of foreign dignitaries. At Versailles, the king alone commanded attention.\n", 'In 1654 Cardinal Mazarin commissioned the royal architect Louis Le Vau to build a new palace for King Louis XIV next to the chateau. The new palace featured a pavilion for the King and another for the Queen, separated by a portico and by a wall connected by arcades to the medieval section of the chateau. The donjon had been transformed into prison in the 15th century. The palace was popular with the King for a time, but once Louis XIV established his residence at Versailles, the château of Vincennes was rarely used.\n', 'The most famous Baroque gardens were the Gardens of Versailles created by Le Notre between 1662 and 1666. It was built around the original small square park of ninety-three hectares before the chateau started for Louis XIII by Jacques Boyceau in 1638. In 1662 following the model of Vaux-le-Vicomte, Le Notre made the park ten times larger, centered on a grand canal which reached to the horizon. The new park was divided into an elaborate grid of flowerbeds, paths, and alleys, decorated with fountains and sculptures. A third enlargement expanded the park by another six thousand five hundred hectares, including forests for hunting and several nearby villages, surrounded by a wall forty-three kilometres long with twenty-two gates.\n', 'The Versailles Synagogue is situated at 10, rue Albert Joly in Versailles in the Department of Yvelines. It is one of the oldest Synagogues in the Île-de-France. Built between 1884 and 1886 by the architect Alfred-Philibert Aldrophe (1834–1895), it was inaugurated in 1886.\n']

knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

The Palace of Versailles, located near Paris, France, was originally constructed as a hunting lodge by King Louis XIII in 1624. This initial structure marked the beginning of what would later become one of the most famous palaces in the world. 

In 1661, King Louis XIV, the son of Louis XIII, began significant renovations and expansions of the original lodge, transforming it into a grand palace that would symbolize absolute monarchy and French art. The expansion involved notable architects, including Louis Le Vau, who was initially commissioned for the project, and Jules Hardouin-Mansart, who took over after Le Vau's death in 1670. Hardouin-Mansart was responsible for many of the palace's defining features, including the Hall of Mirrors and the north and south wings.

Additionally, the gardens of Versailles were designed by landscape architect André Le Nôtre, showcasing the comprehensive nature of the renovations during Louis XIV's reign. The transformation of the hunting lodge into a grand palace occurred over several building campaigns, highlighting the gradual and extensive nature of the project.

Therefore, the original structure was built by King Louis XIII, and it was later significantly enlarged and transformed by King Louis XIV.

**Answer:**
King Louis XIII built the original Palace of Versailles, which was later enlarged and transformed by King Louis XIV.

question_info.question: Who built the original Palace of Versailles that was enlarged by Louis XIV?
passages:
The most important showcase of the French Baroque was the Palace of Versailles. It was begun in 1624 by Louis XIII as a hunting lodge. In 1634, Louis XIII had it enlarged into a chateau by his chief architect and engineer, Philibert Le Roy. In 1661, Louis XIV decided to enlarge it further, without destroying the original. He commissioned Louis Le Vau and Charles le Brun as his architect and designer, and assigned André Le Nôtre to create a grand formal garden that could be viewed from the Chateau, on the model of Vaux-le-Vicomte. When Le Vau died in 1670, the project was given to Jules Hardouin-Mansart, the nephew of Francois Mansart.
Louis XIII's successor, Louis XIV, had a great interest in Versailles. He settled on the royal hunting lodge at Versailles, and over the following decades had it expanded into one of the largest palaces in the world. Beginning in 1661, the architect Louis Le Vau, landscape architect André Le Nôtre, and painter-decorator Charles Lebrun began a detailed renovation and expansion of the château. This was done to fulfill Louis XIV's desire to establish a new centre for the royal court. Following the Treaties of Nijmegen in 1678, he began to gradually move the court to Versailles. The court was officially established there on 6 May 1682.
Based on the success of Vaux le Vicomte, Louis XIV selected Le Vau to construct an immense new palace at Versailles, to augment a smaller palace transformed from a hunting lodge by Louis XIII. This gradually became, over the decades, the master work of the Louis XIV style. Following the death of Le Vau in 1680, Jules Hardouin-Mansart took over the Versailles project; he broke away from the picturesque projections and dome and made a more sober and uniform facade of columns, with a flat roof topped by a balustrade and row of columns (1681). He used the same style to harmonize the other new buildings he created at Versailles, including the Orangerie and the Stables. Hardouin-Mansart constructed the Grand Trianon (completed 1687), single-story royal retreat with arched windows alternating with pairs of columns, and a flat roof and balustrade.
BULLET::::- 1660s – Louis XIV, with the architect Jules Hardouin-Mansart, begins to enlarge the Palace of Versailles (1661).
BULLET::::- The Palace of Versailles is first built by Louis XIII, as a hunting lodge.
With the signing of the Treaty of Nijmegen in 1678, which ended the Dutch War, the third building campaign at Versailles began (1678–1684). Under the direction of the architect, Jules Hardouin-Mansart, the Palace of Versailles acquired much of the look that it has today. In addition to the Hall of Mirrors, Hardouin-Mansart designed the north and south wings, which were used, respectively, by the nobility and Princes of the Blood, and the "Orangerie". Le Brun was occupied not only with the interior decoration of the new additions of the palace, but also collaborated with Le Nôtre's in landscaping the palace gardens. As symbol of France's new prominence as a European super-power, Louis XIV officially installed his court at Versailles in May 1682.
Over the course of four building campaigns, Louis converted a hunting lodge built by Louis XIII into the spectacular Palace of Versailles. With the exception of the current Royal Chapel (built near the end of Louis' reign), the palace achieved much of its current appearance after the third building campaign, which was followed by an official move of the royal court to Versailles on 6 May 1682. Versailles became a dazzling, awe-inspiring setting for state affairs and the reception of foreign dignitaries. At Versailles, the king alone commanded attention.
In 1654 Cardinal Mazarin commissioned the royal architect Louis Le Vau to build a new palace for King Louis XIV next to the chateau. The new palace featured a pavilion for the King and another for the Queen, separated by a portico and by a wall connected by arcades to the medieval section of the chateau. The donjon had been transformed into prison in the 15th century. The palace was popular with the King for a time, but once Louis XIV established his residence at Versailles, the château of Vincennes was rarely used.
The most famous Baroque gardens were the Gardens of Versailles created by Le Notre between 1662 and 1666. It was built around the original small square park of ninety-three hectares before the chateau started for Louis XIII by Jacques Boyceau in 1638. In 1662 following the model of Vaux-le-Vicomte, Le Notre made the park ten times larger, centered on a grand canal which reached to the horizon. The new park was divided into an elaborate grid of flowerbeds, paths, and alleys, decorated with fountains and sculptures. A third enlargement expanded the park by another six thousand five hundred hectares, including forests for hunting and several nearby villages, surrounded by a wall forty-three kilometres long with twenty-two gates.
The Versailles Synagogue is situated at 10, rue Albert Joly in Versailles in the Department of Yvelines. It is one of the oldest Synagogues in the Île-de-France. Built between 1884 and 1886 by the architect Alfred-Philibert Aldrophe (1834–1895), it was inaugurated in 1886.
